mn31:1.1.comm: This discourse is a favorite among monastics, depicting an ideal life of simplicity and friendship. The introduction recurs at Kd 10:4.2.1 and, with a different teaching portion, at MN 128:81. In both those cases it is set after the Buddha left the quarreling monks of Kosambī. | This discourse and MN 128 appear to be influenced by Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3, a famous dialogue where an unusually reluctant Yājñavalkya is repeatedly pressed by King Janaka to reveal the true nature of a person’s light. At SN 7.9:14.4 this passage is alluded to directly.

mn31:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā nātike viharati giñjakāvasathe.
mn31:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying at Ñātika in the brick house.
mn31:1.2.comm: Ñātika (also spelled nātika, or nādika; Sanskrit jñātṛka; Prākrit nāyika) was the clan to which the Jain leader Mahāvīra (called Nāṭaputta, i.e. Ñātiputta) belonged. This is the chief town of the clan. It was part of the Vajjian Federation (See DN 16:2.5.1). | Over a millennium previously, the Indus Valley Civilization had built cities of fired brick with standardized size and construction methods, but in the Buddha’s day most buildings were wood. This is the only brick building mentioned in the suttas, although brick construction is also discussed in the Vinaya.

mn31:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā ca anuruddho āyasmā ca nandiyo āyasmā ca kimilo gosiṅgasālavanadāye viharanti.
mn31:2.1.eng: Now at that time the venerables Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila were staying in the sal forest park at Gosiṅga.
mn31:2.1.comm: Anuruddha was the brother of Ānanda and Mahānāma (Kd 17:1.1.3) which, according to the commentary, makes the Buddha his cousin. He was an exponent of mindfulness meditation (SN 52.1, etc.) and master of clairvoyance (AN 1.192:1.1. | Kimbila was one of the seven leading Sakyans, including Anuruddha and Ānanda, who went forth together (Kd 17:1.4.1). | Several Nandiyas are known in the suttas, one of whom was a Sakyan (SN 55.40, AN 11.13; the root nand (“joy”) was a popular choice for Sakyan names: Ānanda, Nanda, Upananda). While Nandiya is not mentioned as having gone forth with the seven, Kimbila refers to their group as the “Sakyan friends” in his verses at Thag 2.18, so it seems likely he was indeed the Sakyan Nandiya; perhaps he went forth later than his friends.

mn31:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena gosiṅgasālavanadāyo tenupasaṅkami.
mn31:3.1.eng: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to that park.

mn31:3.2.pli: Addasā kho dāyapālo bhagavantaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
mn31:3.2.eng: The park keeper saw the Buddha coming off in the distance
mn31:3.2.comm: This is one of several instances showing that the Buddha looked like an ordinary ascetic (see also DN 2:11.2, MN 140:5.11).

mn31:3.5.eng: There are three gentlemen staying here whose nature is to desire self-knowledge.
mn31:3.5.comm: Attakāmarūpa is glossed by the commentary as “those whose nature is to desire their own welfare”. In the Vinaya (attakāma) means to serve “one’s own desires” (Bu Ss 4). But here it draws on Yājnavalkya’s description of one whose form is such that, having attained their only desire, the Self, they have become without desire (ātmakāmam āptakāmam akāmaṁ rūpaṁ, Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 14.7.1.21, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.21. Cf. niṣkāma āptakāma ātmakāmo, Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 14.7.2.8, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.4.6. In both cases the Bṛhadāraṇyaka reverses the sequence of āpta … ātma.) This describes a sage who is fully immersed in the realization of Brahman in death or dreamless sleep. Such realization is a form of “knowledge” (veda). Here the suffix -rūpa does not mean “seemingly”, nor is it to be discarded as a mere idiom, but has the sense given in the commentary, a person’s true form or true nature (sabhāva). This is, of course, not a Buddhist concept. But it is spoken by the keeper of a park (not a monastery) who fails to even recognize the Buddha. There is no reason he should be Buddhist. To this day, Buddhist monastics are received with kindness and unhesitatingly supported by Hindus, who readily interpret and describe the monastics’ practice in their own terms.

mn31:4.1.pli: Assosi kho āyasmā anuruddho dāyapālassa bhagavatā saddhiṃ mantayamānassa.
mn31:4.1.eng: Anuruddha heard the park keeper conversing with the Buddha,

mn31:4.3.eng: “Don’t keep the Buddha out, good park keeper!

mn31:4.4.eng: Our Teacher, the Blessed One, has arrived.”

mn31:4.5.pli: Atha kho āyasmā anuruddho yenāyasmā ca nandiyo āyasmā ca kimilo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantañca nandiyaṃ āyasmantañca kimilaṃ etadavoca:
mn31:4.5.eng: Then Anuruddha went to Nandiya and Kimbila, and said to them,

mn31:4.6.eng: “Come forth, venerables, come forth! Our Teacher, the Blessed One, has arrived!”

mn31:5.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ca anuruddho āyasmā ca nandiyo āyasmā ca kimilo bhagavantaṃ paccuggantvā—
mn31:5.1.eng: Then Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila came out to greet the Buddha.

mn31:5.2.pli: eko bhagavato pattacīvaraṃ paṭiggahesi, eko āsanaṃ paññapesi, eko pādodakaṃ upaṭṭhāpesi.
mn31:5.2.eng: One received his bowl and robe, one spread out a seat, and one set out water for washing his feet.

mn31:5.3.eng: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out,

mn31:5.5.pli: Tepi kho āyasmanto bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
mn31:5.5.eng: Those venerables bowed and sat down to one side.

mn31:5.6.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:

mn31:5.7.pli: “Kacci vo, anuruddhā, khamanīyaṃ, kacci yāpanīyaṃ, kacci piṇḍakena na kilamathā”ti?
mn31:5.7.eng: “I hope you’re keeping well, Anuruddha and friends; I hope you’re all right. And I hope you’re having no trouble getting almsfood.”
mn31:5.7.comm: The text refers to “Anuruddhas” in plural, referring to the group via their most senior member.

mn31:5.8.pli: “Khamanīyaṃ, bhagavā, yāpanīyaṃ, bhagavā; na ca mayaṃ, bhante, piṇḍakena kilamāmā”ti.
mn31:5.8.eng: “We’re keeping well, Blessed One, we’re getting by. And we have no trouble getting almsfood.”

mn31:6.1.pli: “Kacci pana vo, anuruddhā, samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā khīrodakībhūtā aññamaññaṃ piyacakkhūhi sampassantā viharathā”ti?
mn31:6.1.eng: “I hope you’re living in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes?”
mn31:6.1.comm: The emphasis on harmonious living fits the accounts in Kd 10:4.2.1 and MN 128, where the Buddha had just left the quarreling community of Kosambī. This suggests that the introduction belongs there, when the three friends were practicing together in the Eastern Bamboo Park near Kosambī. The current sutta is set around 400 kms to the east near Vesālī, and it is hardly likely that the Buddha went straight there after leaving Kosambī. In addition, in MN 128 the three friends are still developing their meditation, whereas in the current sutta they have already achieved arahantship. Also, the location there is said to be the site of a hall for Vedic rituals, which suits the evidently non-Buddhist park keeper. It seems that the popular introduction of MN 128 was reused to frame a later conversation with the three friends, despite the implausibility of the same events happening in the same way twice.

mn31:6.2.pli: “Taggha mayaṃ, bhante, samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā khīrodakībhūtā aññamaññaṃ piyacakkhūhi sampassantā viharāmā”ti.
mn31:6.2.eng: “Indeed, sir, we live in harmony like this.”

mn31:6.3.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tumhe, anuruddhā, samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā khīrodakībhūtā aññamaññaṃ piyacakkhūhi sampassantā viharathā”ti?
mn31:6.3.eng: “But how do you live this way?”

mn31:7.3.eng: to live together with spiritual companions such as these.’

mn31:7.4.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, imesu āyasmantesu mettaṃ kāyakammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ āvi ceva raho ca;
mn31:7.4.eng: I consistently treat these venerables with kindness by way of body, speech, and mind, both in public and in private.
mn31:7.4.comm: These are three of the six “warm-hearted qualities” of MN 48:6.2 and AN 6.11:1.1.

mn31:7.5.pli: mettaṃ vacīkammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ āvi ceva raho ca;

mn31:7.6.pli: mettaṃ manokammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ āvi ceva raho ca.

mn31:7.8.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ sakaṃ cittaṃ nikkhipitvā imesaṃyeva āyasmantānaṃ cittassa vasena vatteyyan’ti.
mn31:7.8.eng: ‘Why don’t I set aside my own ideas and just go along with these venerables’ ideas?’

mn31:7.9.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhante, sakaṃ cittaṃ nikkhipitvā imesaṃyeva āyasmantānaṃ cittassa vasena vattāmi.

mn31:7.10.pli: Nānā hi kho no, bhante, kāyā ekañca pana maññe cittan”ti.
mn31:7.10.eng: Though we’re different in body, sir, we’re one in mind, it seems to me.”

mn31:7.11.eng: And the venerables Nandiya and Kimbila spoke likewise, and they added:

mn31:7.16.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, imesu āyasmantesu mettaṃ kāyakammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ āvi ceva raho ca,

mn31:7.17.pli: mettaṃ vacīkammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ āvi ceva raho ca,

mn31:7.18.pli: mettaṃ manokammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ āvi ceva raho ca.

mn31:7.20.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ sakaṃ cittaṃ nikkhipitvā imesaṃyeva āyasmantānaṃ cittassa vasena vatteyyan’ti.

mn31:7.21.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhante, sakaṃ cittaṃ nikkhipitvā imesaṃyeva āyasmantānaṃ cittassa vasena vattāmi.

mn31:7.22.pli: Nānā hi kho no, bhante, kāyā ekañca pana maññe cittan”ti.

mn31:7.23.pli: “Evaṃ kho mayaṃ, bhante, samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā khīrodakībhūtā aññamaññaṃ piyacakkhūhi sampassantā viharāmā”ti.
mn31:7.23.eng: “That’s how we live in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes.”

mn31:8.2.pli: Kacci pana vo, anuruddhā, appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharathā”ti?
mn31:8.2.eng: But I hope you’re living diligently, keen, and resolute?”
mn31:8.2.comm: Normally I render viharati in such instances as “meditate”. But Anuruddha’s response avoids talking about meditation. I think he is deliberately avoiding the topic, skirting the obvious intended meaning by seizing on an ambiguity. His reticence echoes Yājñavalkya’s reticence to answer Janaka on the topic of a person’s light (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.1).

mn31:9.1.pli: “Taggha mayaṃ, bhante, appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharāmā”ti.

mn31:9.2.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tumhe, anuruddhā, appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharathā”ti?
mn31:9.2.eng: “But how do you live this way?”

mn31:9.3.pli: “Idha, bhante, amhākaṃ yo paṭhamaṃ gāmato piṇḍāya paṭikkamati so āsanāni paññapeti, pānīyaṃ paribhojanīyaṃ upaṭṭhāpeti, avakkārapātiṃ upaṭṭhāpeti.
mn31:9.3.eng: “In this case, sir, whoever returns first from almsround prepares the seats, and puts out the drinking water and the rubbish bin.

mn31:9.4.pli: Yo pacchā gāmato piṇḍāya paṭikkamati, sace hoti bhuttāvaseso sace ākaṅkhati bhuñjati, no ce ākaṅkhati appaharite vā chaḍḍeti, appāṇake vā udake opilāpeti.
mn31:9.4.eng: If there’s anything left over, whoever returns last eats it if they like. Otherwise they throw it out where there is little that grows, or drop it into water that has no living creatures.

mn31:9.5.pli: So āsanāni paṭisāmeti, pānīyaṃ paribhojanīyaṃ paṭisāmeti, avakkārapātiṃ paṭisāmeti, bhattaggaṃ sammajjati.
mn31:9.5.eng: Then they put away the seats, drinking water, and rubbish bin, and sweep the refectory.

mn31:9.6.pli: Yo passati pānīyaghaṭaṃ vā paribhojanīyaghaṭaṃ vā vaccaghaṭaṃ vā rittaṃ tucchaṃ so upaṭṭhāpeti.
mn31:9.6.eng: If someone sees that the pot of water for washing, drinking, or the toilet is empty they set it up.

mn31:9.7.pli: Sacassa hoti avisayhaṃ, hatthavikārena dutiyaṃ āmantetvā hatthavilaṅghakena upaṭṭhāpema, na tveva mayaṃ, bhante, tappaccayā vācaṃ bhindāma.
mn31:9.7.eng: If he can’t do it, he summons another with a wave of the hand, and they set it up by lending each other a hand to lift. But we don’t break into speech for that reason.
mn31:9.7.comm: For hatthavilaṅghaka (“lending a hand up”) see MN 125:9.2. | The Chinese parallels (MA 128 at T i 729c9 and EA 24.8 at T ii 629a23) both add that they then retire for meditation.

mn31:9.8.pli: Pañcāhikaṃ kho pana mayaṃ, bhante, sabbarattikaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sannisīdāma.
mn31:9.8.eng: And every five days we sit together for the whole night and discuss the teachings.
mn31:9.8.comm: That is, three times in each uposatha period lasting a fortnight. | The Chinese parallels add that they might also sit in noble silence (in accord with MN 26:4.13).

mn31:9.9.pli: Evaṃ kho mayaṃ, bhante, appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharāmā”ti.
mn31:9.9.eng: That’s how we live diligently, keen, and resolute.”
mn31:9.9.comm: Here the Vinaya account ends, as it is concerned with the settlement of the quarrel among the monks of Kosambī.

mn31:10.2.pli: Atthi pana vo, anuruddhā, evaṃ appamattānaṃ ātāpīnaṃ pahitattānaṃ viharantānaṃ uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti?
mn31:10.2.eng: But as you live diligently like this, have you achieved any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, a comfortable meditation?”

mn31:10.4.pli: Idha mayaṃ, bhante, yāvadeva ākaṅkhāma vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāma.
mn31:10.4.eng: Whenever we want, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, we enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
mn31:10.4.comm: The first absorption is defined at Bu Pj 4:4.1.3.1 as the most basic “superhuman distinction”. Thus Anuruddha is answering the question directly but humbly, revealing as little as possible.

mn31:10.5.pli: Ayaṃ kho no, bhante, amhākaṃ appamattānaṃ ātāpīnaṃ pahitattānaṃ viharantānaṃ uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti.
mn31:10.5.eng: This is a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, a comfortable meditation, that we have achieved while living diligent, keen, and resolute.”

mn31:11-13.2.pli: Etassa pana vo, anuruddhā, vihārassa samatikkamāya etassa vihārassa paṭippassaddhiyā atthañño uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti?
mn31:11-13.2.eng: But have you achieved any other superhuman distinction for going beyond and stilling that meditation?”
mn31:11-13.2.comm: Samatikkamāya (“for going beyond”) is used in a similar sense at MN 10:47.1.

mn31:11-13.4.pli: Idha mayaṃ, bhante, yāvadeva ākaṅkhāma vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāma.
mn31:11-13.4.eng: Whenever we want, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, we enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

mn31:11-13.5.pli: Etassa, bhante, vihārassa samatikkamāya etassa vihārassa paṭippassaddhiyā ayamañño uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti.
mn31:11-13.5.eng: This is another superhuman distinction that we have achieved for going beyond and stilling that meditation.”

mn31:14.2.pli: Etassa pana vo, anuruddhā, vihārassa samatikkamāya etassa vihārassa paṭippassaddhiyā atthañño uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti?
mn31:14.2.eng: But have you achieved any other superhuman distinction for going beyond and stilling that meditation?”

mn31:14.4.pli: Idha mayaṃ, bhante, yāvadeva ākaṅkhāma pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhakā ca viharāma, satā ca sampajānā, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedema, yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāma.
mn31:14.4.eng: Whenever we want, with the fading away of rapture, we enter and remain in the third absorption, where we meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

mn31:14.5.pli: Etassa, bhante, vihārassa samatikkamāya etassa vihārassa paṭippassaddhiyā ayamañño uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti.
mn31:14.5.eng: This is another superhuman distinction that we have achieved for going beyond and stilling that meditation.”

mn31:15.2.pli: Etassa pana vo, anuruddhā, vihārassa samatikkamāya etassa vihārassa paṭippassaddhiyā atthañño uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti?
mn31:15.2.eng: But have you achieved any other superhuman distinction for going beyond and stilling that meditation?”

mn31:15.4.pli: Idha mayaṃ, bhante, yāvadeva ākaṅkhāma sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāma.
mn31:15.4.eng: Whenever we want, with the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, we enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

mn31:15.5.pli: Etassa, bhante, vihārassa samatikkamāya etassa vihārassa paṭippassaddhiyā ayamañño uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti.
mn31:15.5.eng: This is another superhuman distinction that we have achieved for going beyond and stilling that meditation.”

mn31:16.2.pli: Etassa pana vo, anuruddhā, vihārassa samatikkamāya etassa vihārassa paṭippassaddhiyā atthañño uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti?
mn31:16.2.eng: But have you achieved any other superhuman distinction for going beyond and stilling that meditation?”

mn31:16.4.pli: Idha mayaṃ, bhante, yāvadeva ākaṅkhāma sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharāma.
mn31:16.4.eng: Whenever we want, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, we enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space.

mn31:16.5.pli: Etassa, bhante, vihārassa samatikkamāya etassa vihārassa paṭippassaddhiyā ayamañño uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti.
mn31:16.5.eng: This is another superhuman distinction that we have achieved for going beyond and stilling that meditation.”

mn31:17.2.pli: Etassa pana vo, anuruddhā, vihārassa samatikkamāya etassa vihārassa paṭippassaddhiyā atthañño uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti?
mn31:17.2.eng: But have you achieved any other superhuman distinction for going beyond and stilling that meditation?”

mn31:17.4.pli: Idha mayaṃ, bhante, yāvadeva ākaṅkhāma sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharāma …pe…
mn31:17.4.eng: Whenever we want, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, we enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness. …

mn31:17.5.pli: sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharāma …pe…
mn31:17.5.eng: going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, we enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness. …

mn31:17.6.pli: sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharāma.
mn31:17.6.eng: going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, we enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

mn31:17.7.pli: Etassa, bhante, vihārassa samatikkamāya etassa vihārassa paṭippassaddhiyā ayamañño uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti.
mn31:17.7.eng: This is another superhuman distinction that we have achieved for going beyond and stilling that meditation.”

mn31:18.2.pli: Etassa pana vo, anuruddhā, vihārassa samatikkamāya etassa vihārassa paṭippassaddhiyā atthañño uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti?
mn31:18.2.eng: But have you achieved any other superhuman distinction for going beyond and stilling that meditation?”

mn31:18.4.pli: Idha mayaṃ, bhante, yāvadeva ākaṅkhāma sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharāma, paññāya ca no disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā.
mn31:18.4.eng: Whenever we want, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, we enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, our defilements have come to an end.

mn31:18.5.pli: Etassa, bhante, vihārassa samatikkamāya etassa vihārassa paṭippassaddhiyā ayamañño uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro.
mn31:18.5.eng: This is another superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, a comfortable meditation, that we have achieved for going beyond and stilling that meditation.

mn31:18.6.pli: Imamhā ca mayaṃ, bhante, phāsuvihārā aññaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ uttaritaraṃ vā paṇītataraṃ vā na samanupassāmā”ti.
mn31:18.6.eng: And we don’t see any better or finer way of meditating comfortably than this.”

mn31:18.8.pli: Imamhā phāsuvihārā uttaritaro vā paṇītataro vā phāsuvihāro natthī”ti.
mn31:18.8.eng: There is no better or finer way of meditating comfortably than this.”

mn31:19.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantañca anuruddhaṃ āyasmantañca nandiyaṃ āyasmantañca kimilaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṃsetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
mn31:19.1.eng: Then the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired the venerables Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila with a Dhamma talk, after which he got up from his seat and left.

mn31:20.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ca anuruddho āyasmā ca nandiyo āyasmā ca kimilo bhagavantaṃ anusaṃyāyitvā tato paṭinivattitvā āyasmā ca nandiyo āyasmā ca kimilo āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ etadavocuṃ:
mn31:20.1.eng: The venerables then accompanied the Buddha for a little way before turning back. Nandiya and Kimbila said to Anuruddha,

mn31:20.2.pli: “kiṃ nu kho mayaṃ āyasmato anuruddhassa evamārocimha:
mn31:20.2.eng: “Did we ever tell you that we had

mn31:20.3.pli: ‘imāsañca imāsañca vihārasamāpattīnaṃ mayaṃ lābhino’ti, yaṃ no āyasmā anuruddho bhagavato sammukhā yāva āsavānaṃ khayā pakāsetī”ti?
mn31:20.3.eng: gained such and such meditations and attainments, up to the ending of defilements, as you revealed to the Buddha?”
mn31:20.3.comm: Even such close monks did not reveal their attainments to each other, a testament to their character. This is a reminder of the virtue of discretion when speaking of such subtle matters. They are not things to be bandied about in common conversation.

mn31:20.4.eng: “The venerables did not tell me that they had

mn31:20.5.pli: ‘imāsañca imāsañca vihārasamāpattīnaṃ mayaṃ lābhino’ti, api ca me āyasmantānaṃ cetasā ceto paricca vidito:
mn31:20.5.eng: gained such meditations and attainments. But I discovered it by encompassing your minds,

mn31:20.9.eng: I answered when the Buddha directly asked about it.”

mn31:21.1.pli: Atha kho dīgho parajano yakkho yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho dīgho parajano yakkho bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn31:21.1.eng: Then the native spirit Dīgha Parajana went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,
mn31:21.1.comm: Parajana means “stranger” (Mil 6.3.1:13.2) or “strange spirit” (MN 25:5.20). The commentary identifies him with the Dīgha of DN 32:10.18. He must have been the deity of a local shrine. This passage shows how the intercession of even such a humble spirit can resound among all the gods.

mn31:21.2.eng: “The Vajjis are lucky! The Vajjian people are so very lucky
mn31:21.2.comm: The praise that follows is unusually effusive and can be compared with the equally unusual recounting of the enlightened devotees of Ñātika (DN 16:2.5.1). Both passages serve to extol Buddhism in the home of Mahāvīra, the Buddha’s elder rival.

mn31:21.3.pli: yattha tathāgato viharati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho, ime ca tayo kulaputtā—
mn31:21.3.eng: that the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha stays there, as well as these three gentlemen,

mn31:21.4.pli: āyasmā ca anuruddho, āyasmā ca nandiyo, āyasmā ca kimilo”ti.
mn31:21.4.eng: the venerables Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila.”

mn31:21.5.pli: Dīghassa parajanassa yakkhassa saddaṃ sutvā bhummā devā saddamanussāvesuṃ:
mn31:21.5.eng: Hearing the cry of Dīgha Parajana, the earth gods raised the cry …

mn31:21.7.pli: yattha tathāgato viharati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho, ime ca tayo kulaputtā—

mn31:21.8.pli: āyasmā ca anuruddho, āyasmā ca nandiyo, āyasmā ca kimilo”ti.

mn31:21.9.pli: Bhummānaṃ devānaṃ saddaṃ sutvā cātumahārājikā devā …pe…
mn31:21.9.eng: Hearing the cry of the earth gods, the gods of the four great kings …

mn31:21.13.eng: the gods who love to create …

mn31:21.14.eng: the gods who control what is created by others …

mn31:21.15.eng: the gods of the Divinity’s host raised the cry,

mn31:21.16.eng: “The Vajjis are lucky! The Vajjian people are so very lucky

mn31:21.17.pli: yattha tathāgato viharati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho, ime ca tayo kulaputtā—
mn31:21.17.eng: that the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha stays there, as well as these three gentlemen,

mn31:21.18.pli: āyasmā ca anuruddho, āyasmā ca nandiyo, āyasmā ca kimilo”ti.
mn31:21.18.eng: the venerables Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila.”

mn31:21.19.pli: Itiha te āyasmanto tena khaṇena tena layena tena muhuttena yāva brahmalokā viditā ahesuṃ.
mn31:21.19.eng: And so at that moment, that second, that hour, those venerables were known as far as the realm of divinity.

mn31:22.1.eng: “That’s so true, Dīgha! That’s so true!

mn31:22.2.pli: Yasmāpi, dīgha, kulā ete tayo kulaputtā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā, tañcepi kulaṃ ete tayo kulaputte pasannacittaṃ anussareyya, tassapāssa kulassa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya.
mn31:22.2.eng: If the family from which those three gentlemen went forth from the lay life to homelessness were to recollect those venerables with confident heart, that would be for that family’s lasting welfare and happiness.

mn31:22.3.pli: Yasmāpi, dīgha, kulaparivaṭṭā ete tayo kulaputtā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā, so cepi kulaparivaṭṭo ete tayo kulaputte pasannacitto anussareyya, tassapāssa kulaparivaṭṭassa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya.

mn31:22.4.pli: Yasmāpi, dīgha, gāmā ete tayo kulaputtā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā, so cepi gāmo ete tayo kulaputte pasannacitto anussareyya, tassapāssa gāmassa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya.

mn31:22.5.pli: Yasmāpi, dīgha, nigamā ete tayo kulaputtā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā, so cepi nigamo ete tayo kulaputte pasannacitto anussareyya, tassapāssa nigamassa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya.

mn31:22.6.pli: Yasmāpi, dīgha, nagarā ete tayo kulaputtā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā, tañcepi nagaraṃ ete tayo kulaputte pasannacittaṃ anussareyya, tassapāssa nagarassa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya.

mn31:22.7.pli: Yasmāpi, dīgha, janapadā ete tayo kulaputtā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā, so cepi janapado ete tayo kulaputte pasannacitto anussareyya, tassapāssa janapadassa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya.

mn31:22.8.pli: Sabbe cepi, dīgha, khattiyā ete tayo kulaputte pasannacittā anussareyyuṃ, sabbesānampāssa khattiyānaṃ dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya.

mn31:22.11.pli: sabbe cepi, dīgha, suddā ete tayo kulaputte pasannacittā anussareyyuṃ, sabbesānampāssa suddānaṃ dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya.
mn31:22.11.eng: all the workers were to recollect those venerables with confident heart, that would be for all those menials’ lasting welfare and happiness.

mn31:22.12.pli: Sadevako cepi, dīgha, loko samārako sabrahmako sassamaṇabrāhmaṇī pajā sadevamanussā ete tayo kulaputte pasannacittā anussareyya, sadevakassapāssa lokassa samārakassa sabrahmakassa sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya.
mn31:22.12.eng: If the whole world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—were to recollect those venerables with confident heart, that would be for the whole world’s lasting welfare and happiness.

mn31:22.13.pli: Passa, dīgha, yāva ete tayo kulaputtā bahujanahitāya paṭipannā bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya, atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan”ti.
mn31:22.13.eng: See, Dīgha, how those three gentlemen are practicing for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans!”

mn31:22.14.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn31:22.15.pli: Attamano dīgho parajano yakkho bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
mn31:22.15.eng: Satisfied, the native spirit Dīgha Parajana approved what the Buddha said.
